title: Investigation of Anisotropic Electronic Structure in Graphite by Momentum-Resolved Electron Energy Loss Spectroscopy (ω-q Mapping) and Electron Spectroscopic Diffraction Patterns
content: Momentum (q)-resolved electron energy loss spectroscopy (q-EELS), which analyzes the electron dispersion as a function of frequency (ω) and q transfer (so-called ω-q maps), has been widely employed to investigate the dispersion of surface/volume plasmons and anisotropic electronic excitations. The recent demonstration of q-EELS in aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC-STEM) has become an important advancement in this field [1, 2]. AC-STEM enables adjusting the convergent semi-angle (α angle) from 20∼ 40 mrad to 1∼3 mrad to resolve the overlapped diffraction discs that would otherwise average out all possible anisotropic electronic excitations. Combining with an electron monochromator to achieve the energy resolution of a few meV, q-EELS in AC-STEM has successfully been applied to construct the ω-q maps of the vibration phonon dispersion [1, 2]. However, the α angle of 1∼3 mrad in AC-STEM is still approximately one order of magnitude larger than the α angle (less than 0.1 mrad) for selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) in conventional TEM (C-TEM) using parallel electron beams [3]. C-TEM-EELS has been reported to achieve the q resolution approaching the long-wavelength limit to investigate the dispersions for surface plasmons [3, 4]. Meanwhile, the electron spectroscopic diffraction (ESD) patterns obtained from energy-filtered TEM (EFTEM) [5] have also been explored to study the anisotropic excitations in graphite [5], boron nitride [6], and lead selenide [7], demonstrating its potential for the investigation of electronic anisotropy in materials. Here, we use both ω-q maps and ESD patterns in C-TEM to study the anisotropic dispersion in graphite.
